timeline.message: Restore null behavior for greatest and least
Restore null behavior for array_max and array_min

timeline.author: martint

replies.bodyText: It's testing that the loop condition handling is correct when there are more than two values.
replies.author: electrum

timeline.bodyText: You do not even need to add a new test, nice.
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure what this comment means.

findepi

replies.bodyText: Actually the cases above are also for DOUBLE, not REAL
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: This remained unanswered, so we don't have a test for NULL with REAL type just yet.
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: Add a greatest and least test cases for DOUBLE and REAL with 1,NaN,3 and 1,NULL,NaN,4
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: This PR only covers restoring null behavior.  NaN can be in another PR
replies.author: dain

timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: Duplicate with what? They are different input types
replies.author: electrum
findepi

timeline.author: findepi
findepi

replies.bodyText: Actually the cases above are also for DOUBLE, not REAL
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
Before c95e937 the expected values here were different -- here and in some other places NaN was expected. See
https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/f04fa5ca8de1015629a94693740dfbc641e55784/presto-main/src/test/java/io/prestosql/type/TestArrayOperators.java#L608-L612
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: You're right, though that seems like a different issue, and a bug. It's not clear why NaN would be returned over NULL, but non-NaN values would return NULL.
replies.author: electrum

replies.bodyText:
According to the documentation, it is a bug:

Like most other functions in Presto, they return null if any argument is null.
replies.author: electrum

replies.bodyText: I think the logic can be "return NaN when any of the compared values is NaN" and "NULL means unknown, so return unknown result when any of the compared values is unknown but, unless the result will be NaN regardless of the unknown value"
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: Anyway, even if want to change the behavior, I'd strongly prefer to restore pre-344 behavior to clear "release blocker" and then fix whatever remains to be fixed on top of that.
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
Actually, that quote is from greatest/least. The only documentation for array_min is

Returns the minimum value of input array.
replies.author: electrum
